quest_title: The resistance of a wire is \(\text{r}\) ohm. The wire is stretched to double its length. Now the resistance of wire in ohm is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} R &=\rho \cfrac{l}{A} \times \cfrac{l}{l} \\ R &=\rho \cfrac{l^2}{V} \\ \Rightarrow & R \propto l^2 \\ & \cfrac{r^{\prime}}{r}=\left(\cfrac{l^{\prime}}{l}\right)^{2}=\left(\cfrac{2 l}{l}\right)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow & r^{\prime}=4 r \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: The roots of the equation \(x^{2/3} +x^{1/3} -2=0\) are
explanation_txt:
Let \( x^{1/3} = t \)

Then the given equation becomes:

\( t^2 + t - 2 = 0 \)

Its roots are:

\( t = \cfrac{-1 \pm \sqrt{9} }{2} = 1 \, or \, -2 \)

Since, \(x = t^3 \)

the possible values of \(x\) are \(1\) or \(-8\)

quest_title: The magnifying power of a compound microscope is 95 and the distance of object from objective is (1/3.8)cm. The focal length of objective is 1/4cm then magnification of eye lens will be
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{m}=\cfrac{\mathrm{f}}{\mathrm{u}-\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{\cfrac{1}{4}}{\cfrac{1}{3.8}-\cfrac{1}{4}}=19\)

\(\mathrm{m}=\mathrm{m}_{0} \times \mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{e}}\)

\(\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{e}}=95 / 19=5\)

quest_title: Carbon tetrachioride has no net dipole moment because of
ans3_txt: Similar sizes of carbon and chlorine atoms
ans4_txt: Similar electron affinities of carbon and chlorine.
explanation_txt: As all the bonds are identical due of similar atoms bonded to Carbon, and the carbon atom has no lone pairs, the geometry is symmetric, thus making the net dipole moment in the compound zero.
question_plain_title: Carbon tetrachioride has no net dipole moment because of
explanation_plain_text: As all the bonds are identical due of similar atoms bonded to Carbon, and the carbon atom has no lone pairs, the geometry is symmetric, thus making the net dipole moment in the compound zero.
ans3_plain_text: Similar sizes of carbon and chlorine atoms
ans4_plain_text: Similar electron affinities of carbon and chlorine.

quest_title: \( \displaystyle \lim_{x \to \theta}\cfrac{xcot\theta - \theta cotx}{x - \theta } \) =
explanation_txt:
As \(x \to \theta\) the limit takes \(0/0\) form.

Using L-Hopital's rule:

\(\begin{align} \displaystyle L & = \lim_{x \to \theta} \cfrac{x \cot \theta - \theta \cot x}{x - \theta} \\ & = \lim_{x \to \theta} \cfrac{ \cot \theta + \theta \text{cosec}^2x}{1} \\ & = \cot \theta + \theta \text{cosec}^2 \theta \end{align}\)
question_plain_title: =
explanation_plain_text:
As the limit takes form.

Using L-Hopital's rule:
ans1_plain_text: cos
ans2_plain_text: sin -
ans3_plain_text: cos-
ans4_plain_text: cot

quest_title: Three perfect gases at absolute temperature T\({}_{1}\), T\({}_{2}\), T\({}_{3}\) are mixed whose masses are m\({}_{1}\)m\({}_{2}\) and m\({}_{3}\) and number of molecules n\({}_{1}\), n\({}_{2}\)& n\({}_{3}\) then the temperature of mixture will be
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{aligned} \cfrac{3}{2} \mathrm{k.n}_{1} \mathrm{T}_{1}+\cfrac{3}{2} \mathrm{kn}_{2} \mathrm{T}_{2} &+\cfrac{3}{2} \mathrm{kn}_{3} \mathrm{T}_{3} \\ &=\cfrac{3}{2} \mathrm{k}\left(\mathrm{n}_{1}+\mathrm{n}_{2}+\mathrm{n}_{3}\right) \mathrm{T} \end{aligned}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{T}=\cfrac{n_{1} T_{1}+n_{2} T_{2}+n_{3} T_{3}}{n_{1}+n_{2}+n_{3}}\)

quest_title: When a sound wave of frequency 300Hz passes through a medium the maximum displacement of a particle of the medium is 0.1cm. The maximum velocity of the particle is equal to
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{A}=0.1 \mathrm{cm}\)
\(\mathrm{f}=300 \mathrm{Hz}\)
Maximum particle velocity \(=\mathrm{A} \omega\)
\(=\mathrm{A} \times 2 \pi \mathrm{f}=0.1 \times 2 \pi \times 300=60 \mathrm{\pi cm} / \mathrm{sec}\)

quest_title: A radioactive substance contain 1.6mg of Th\({}^{234}\). After 120 days only 0.05mg half of it remained unchanged. Calculate its life.
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{m}_{0}}=\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{\cfrac{t}{T_{1/2}}}\)
or, \(\cfrac{0.05}{1.60}=\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{\cfrac{t}{T_{1 / 2}}}\)
or, \(\cfrac{1}{32}=\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{\cfrac{t}{T_{1 / 2}}}\)
or, \(\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{5}=\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{\cfrac{t}{T_{1 / 2}}}\)
or, \(T_{1 / 2}=\cfrac{120}{5}=24\) days

quest_title: The weight of zinc (Zn= \(\text{65)\(\,\)displaced}\) by the quantity of current which librated 11200 ml of \(\text{H\(_{2}\)}\) at NTP will be
explanation_txt:
22400 ml of H2 at NTP = 2 gm H2

so, 11200 ml of H2 at NTP = 1 gm H2

Now, using Second law of electrolysis,

\(\cfrac{M_{Zn}}{M_{H_2}} = \cfrac{E_{Zn}}{E_{H_2}}\)

or, \(\cfrac{M_{Zn}}{1} = \cfrac{32.5}{1}\)

\(\therefore M_{Zn} = 32.5\) gm

quest_title: A real root of the equation \(\log _{4} \{ \log _{2} (\sqrt{x+8} -\sqrt{x} )\} =0\) is
explanation_txt:
\(\log _{4} \left\{\, \log _{2} (\sqrt{x+8} -\sqrt{x} )\right\}=0\)

\[\Rightarrow 4^{0} =\log _{2} \left(\sqrt{x+8} -\sqrt{x} \right)\]

\[ \Rightarrow 2^{1} =\sqrt{x+8} -\sqrt{x} \]

\[\Rightarrow 4=x+8+x-2\sqrt{x^{2} +8x} \]

\[\Rightarrow 2\sqrt{x^{2} +8x} =2x+4\]

\[\Rightarrow x^{2} +8x=x^{2} +4+4x\]

\[\Rightarrow 4x=4 \]

\[ \Rightarrow x=1. \]

[It is better to check for options]
question_plain_title: A real root of the equation is
explanation_plain_text: [It is better to check for options]

explanation_txt:

quest_title: A particle moves so that the displacement x of particle is related with time by x\({}^{2}\) = 1+t\({}^{2}\) then acceleration of particle will be
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{x}^{2}=1+\mathrm{t}^{2} \)
\(\text { or, } 2 \mathrm{x} \cfrac{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{x}}{\mathrm{dt}}=2 \mathrm{t} \)
\(\text { or, } \mathrm{x} v=\mathrm{t} \)

\(\text { or, } \mathrm{x} \cfrac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{dt}}+v \cfrac{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{x}}{\mathrm{dt}}=1 \)
\(\text { or, } \mathrm{xa}+v^{2}=1 \)
\(\text { or, } \mathrm{xa}=1-v^{2} \)

\(\text { or, } a=\cfrac{1-v^{2}}{\mathrm{x}}=\cfrac{1-(\mathrm{t}/ \mathrm{x})^{2}}{\mathrm{x}} \quad[\because \mathrm{x} v=\mathrm{t}]\)

\(\quad=\cfrac{x^{2}-t^{2}}{x^{3}}=\cfrac{1}{x}-\cfrac{t^{2}}{x^{3}}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{t}_{2}=\cfrac{40}{22} \times 10 \times \cfrac{4^{2}}{20}=80 \mathrm{sec}\)

quest_title: Identify the wrong statement in the following. Coulomb's law correctly describes the electric force that
ans1_txt: Binds the electrons of an atom to its nucleus
ans2_txt: Binds the protons and neutrons in the nucleus of an atom
ans4_txt: Binds atoms and molecules together to form solids
explanation_txt: Protons and neutrons in the nucleus are very closely held. These nucleons apart having high electrostatic repulsion are held by a special kind of force. Among four fundamental forces of nature, it's strong nuclear force which binds the protons and neutrons in the nucleus of an atom.

quest_title: If the bisectors of the angles between the pairs of lines given by the equation \(a x ^ { 2 } + 2 h x y + b y ^ { 2 } = 0\) and \(a x ^ { 2 } + 2 \ln y + b y ^ { 2 } + \lambda \left( x ^ { 2 } + y ^ { 2 } \right) = 0\) be coincident, then \(\lambda =\)
explanation_txt:
Bisectors of \(a x ^ { 2 } + 2 h x y + b y ^ { 2 } = 0\) are

\(\cfrac { x ^ { 2 } - y ^ { 2 } } { a - b } = \cfrac { x y } { h }\).....(i)

and of \(a x ^ { 2 } + 2 h x y + b y ^ { 2 } + \lambda \left( x ^ { 2 } + y ^ { 2 } \right) = 0\) i.e.,\(( a + \lambda ) x ^ { 2 } + 2 h x y + ( b + \lambda ) v ^ { 2 } = 0\) are

\(\cfrac { x ^ { 2 } - y ^ { 2 } } { ( a + \lambda ) - ( b + \lambda ) } = \cfrac { x y } { h }\) .....(ii)

Which is the same equation as equation (i). Hence for any belonging to real numbers, the lines will have same bisectors.

explanation_plain_text:
Bisectors of are

.....(i)

and of i.e., are

.....(ii)

Which is the same equation as equation (i). Hence for any belonging to real numbers, the lines will have same bisectors.

quest_title: If \(a,\; b,\; c\) are in A.P., then \(\cfrac{(a-c)^{2} }{(b^{2} -ac)} =\)
explanation_txt:
If \(a,\; b,\; c\) are in A.P. \(\Rightarrow \)\(2b=a+c\)

So,

\(\cfrac{(a-c)^{2} }{(b^{2} -ac)} =\cfrac{(a-c)^{2} }{\left\{\left(\cfrac{a+c}{2} \right)^{2} -ac\right\}} \)

\(=\cfrac{(a-c)^{2} 4}{[a^{2} +c^{2} +2ac-4ac]} =\cfrac{4(a-c)^{2} }{(a-c)^{2} } =4.\)

Trick : Put \(a=1,\; b=2,\; c=3\), then the required value is \(\cfrac{4}{1} =4\).

quest_title: Which pair of the following forces will never give resultant force of 2 N?
explanation_txt:
If two vectors \(A\) and \(B\) are given then Range of their resultant can be written as

\(( A - B ) \leq R \leq ( A + B )\)
i.e. \(R _ { max } = A + B\) and \(R _ { \min } = A - B\)

If B = 1 and A = 4 then their resultant will lies in between 3N and 5N. It can never be 2N.

quest_title: The mass of the nucleus of the isotope \({}_{3}\)Li\({}^{7\ }\)is 7.01435 amu. Find its binding energy per nucleon.
explanation_txt:
\(\Delta m=\{(3 \times 1.0073+4 \times 1.0078)-7.01435\} u\)
\(\cfrac{E}{A}=\cfrac{\Delta m \times 931}{7}\)

quest_title: Which one of the following relationship is correct?
explanation_txt:
Dulong and Petit's law states the product of specific heat and the atomic mass of an element in the solid state is approxoximately equal to \(6.4 .\)

Limitations of Dulong and Petit's law,

  • This law is applicable to elements which are in solid state.
  • This law Is applicable to the heavier element. It is not applicable to lighter elements having high melting points.
  • This law gives approximate atomic mass.

quest_title: \(\text{If } f ( x ) = \cos x \cos 2 x \cos 4 x \cos 8 x \cos 16 x , \text { then } f \left( \cfrac { \pi } { 4 } \right)=\)
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { f ( x ) = \cfrac { 2 \sin x \cdot \cos x \cdot \cos 2 x \cdot \cos 4 x \cdot \cos 8 x \cdot \cos 16 } { 2 \sin x } } \\ { \quad = \cfrac { \sin 32 x } { 2 ^ { 5 } \sin x } } \\ { \therefore f ( x ) = \cfrac { 1 } { 32 } \cdot \cfrac { 32 \cos 32 x \cdot \sin x - \cos x \cdot \sin 32 x } { \sin ^ { 2 } x } } \\ { f \left( \cfrac { \pi } { 4 } \right) = \cfrac { 32 \cdot \cfrac { 1 } { \sqrt { 2 } } - \cfrac { 1 } { \sqrt { 2 } } \times 0 } { \sin ^ { 2 } x } = \sqrt { 2 } } \end{array}\)
